comments.commentBody: I notice that no one is really speaking from the side of the coworker. I share a very small office with another woman. We are friends. We have a great relationship. We both got pregant at the same time. She gave birth to a beautiful baby boy. I miscarried. It was very difficult for me to share an office with her when she came back from maternity leave. Seeing her pump, etc was just a reminder of the baby I had lost. My point is everyone has a reason for not wanting to be around someone pumping, etc. There are two sides to this.

Hospital maternity wards are not much more than profit-making baby factories as well.

Children are not toys.

People that get drunk and conceive should not be allowed to have children either, and if we could prevent these fools from breeding the world would be a better place. if you really want a child, adopt one.

Never mind a little screaming baby, how about a screaming 4 yr old who refused to wear a seat belt. We took our adopted daughter, who has emotional issues, to see her grandfather. He was in a wheelchair and could not travel. I was mortified as she carried on for hours and felt so sorry for the whole plane load of people. But her grandfather, who died soon after, got to meet her. We did not take her on a plane again for many years, no way would I ever knwoingly inflict this on other people or myself for that matter.

What # 1,2,3 don't realize is that these immigrants are appealing rulings AND they have the right to do that.  They are not--yet--considered illegal immigrants because they have an appeals process AND the right to be represented.  The article states that more people who have representations win their cases tha those who don't--which means that the people mentioned in the article are following the judicial process of the USA and have been heard and are able to stay here.  Odd how people hear the word "immigrant" and go all nuts--don't bother to read the article and consider what it was about before they spew their prejudice.

He called immigrants facing deportation “the lepers of today.”

“If Jesus was here,” Father Vitaglione said, “these are the people he’d be sitting down with.”

A beautiful story. Better some help than none. I might be more open to Christianity of more Christians had this type of heart.

Christmas in July. One of the country's most influential fascist and media liar Murdoch paying the price for being a criminal. Finally.

Now...let's investigate how the law preventing a person from owning more than one media outlet per city got overturned at the behest and for Murdoch in our Congress.
Guess it's time to investigate all the hacking this jerk has done in the U.S.
This is just business as usual for all of Murdoch's "News" organization.  There’s not a legitimate News outlet in the whole group.  I mean really, look at Fox News.

What do you think about the rest of Murdoch's evil empire?  Do you question whether Fox News would do the same snooping or even worse, just make it all up?  Murdoch is a conservative fabricator.  For conservatives lies and damn lies are the norm.  A little stealing, break-ins, and invasion of privacy are only used to get the message across.  The message is  " you are all too dumb to handle the truth".  Lies are what we are fed from birth to death.  And life after death, could that be the ultimate lie?
How many people have lost their livelihood for the machinations of a few?  Then again, how is that new?

This event is not the demise of a respectable newspaper.  Google and peruse the current online issue of the News of the World,  How can this trash be called serious journalism?  That it's the biggest selling paper in Great Britain speaks poorly of the land of my ancestors. There is no doubt the cash cow that helped fund the rest of Murdoch's despicable empire will materialize in a similar form within the year.

It has to be something big, something that infects the rest of News Corp, because otherwise why would they do something so drastic as can NOTW?

NOTW was the loss leader title that gave Rupe political influence in the UK.

He's prepared to sacrifice that title in order to protect something else - and it won't be Rebekah, no matter what he says. It'll be something that Rebekah knows. And I'm going to bet, given that this is Rebekah, it's something to do with Cameron.

Once the BSkyB acquisition is complete, look for a manufactured outcry from the "British Public" to bring back NOW, with a new, smaller staff, presuming Murdoch's financial analysts conclude it's profitable to do so.

#79 Angela I'm sorry for your loss. And having struggled for years with infertility (though not loss) I did think of that. But (though I agree it is painfully difficult) it comes down to our needing to accept others' situations (just as they need to accept ours). My wheelchair-bound coworker doesn't ask me not to walk down the hall, nor did the co-worker who found out the day before my wedding anniversary that her marriage of 3 decades was ending report me to HR when my hubby had flowers delivered to me that day at work (though believe me, I did wish, considering, that he'd chosen a different way to celebrate).

#78 I'd not have taken extended maternity leave even had it been available to me (and I've watched a family member in Europe bemoan the reality that it has literally cost her money to return to work part-time, as she wanted to do, losing her maternity leave coverage for a paycheck smaller than what she'd have gotten had she stayed home), so, no, extended paid maternity leave doesn't solve the problem, though I agree it's a good idea and believe it's one many women would choose if they could. But not all of us.

About 8 years ago, I flew from Frankfurt to Calgary (about 10 hours) with two of someone else's children "bugging" me the entire flight. Their mother went to sleep, their father vanished (how do you vanish on an a320?) , and 2 young kids bounced on their seats next to me. I made the best of it, made 2 good friends for the flight, let them play games & watch movies on my laptop, had the attendant thank me profusely, and arrived home quite tired.

Now I have 3 kids, 8, 4 and 2 and we travel sometimes. My little brood makes noise. Kids make noise. Noise is a part of life. My little brood have every much the right to be in business or first class as anyone else who can afford a ticket or upgrade to get there. We don't often upgrade to business, but whenever our seat mate sits down I do say, this is my son XXXXXXX and he'll be your audio entertainment for the flight.

Children are a blessing, and a wonder, they are our future, and the hope of all things to come. I would rather hear a noisy child than the silence of none. While I do find a child screaming in pain to be extremely disruptive, my instinct is to help the parent help the child.

Enjoy your children, live for their view. Don't for a moment consider that the noise of a child would bother someone else, because if it does - the problem isn't on your end.

Enjoy your trip and your flight back, good luck getting over the viral thing. Meds don't really work on viral infections, but ipads are incredible children entertainers.

Breastfeeding is like parenting in that it's indescribably wonderful to those who haven't experienced it. The only person in my law office who ever negatively reacted to my pumping at work was a single, childless fellow female attorney (also a friend) who would make a disgusted face every time she saw my pump parts, clean or not. She is also (good-naturedly) judgmental about the fact that I am still nursing my daughter at 22 months. No amount of explanation will dissuade her of her opinion that my breastmilk is gross (although beneficial) and that my daughter should not still be breastfeeding.

Reading the original post and comments made me realize how lucky I was. I was able to pump in my office and, therefore, keep working. I didn't have a lock on my door, so I put a little sign on my door that said, "New baby girl" or something like that. Everyone knew what it meant. The kitchen area was in an open hallway, so I had no choice but to rinse in the kitchen sink. I stored my pumped milk in an opaque tupperware.

I did use the pump wipes in a pinch. But generally, aside from being expensive, I figured that the disposable diapers and milk bags were wreaking havoc enough on the environment without adding another disposable wipe to the mix. So I was one of those who carried the milk-spattered parts the short walk to the kitchen sink. I even had a male attorney come over to chat while I was rinsing one day. He didn't bat an eye.

I've been in three different cities in three different hotel rooms over the last few days in the U.S.

One thing that has struck me very vividly is that the ABC/CBS/NBC networks (and even some local affiiliates) have all had short stories on the goings on of the News Corp. story in Britain, yet I've not seen a single story or even a mention on Fox News or a Fox affiliate here in the US regarding this major story.
Oldest corporate scam there is: do something very wrong, close down so wronged parties cannot sue, reopen under new name, same game, same staff. Murdoch the grifter stays calm, carries on.

Rupert Murdoch has long been known in Australia as 'the dirty Digger'. He also has the reputation of being a 'hands on' media proprietor. It defies belief that he was not aware of what News of the World was up to.

To me, all these high-and-mighty childless folks who are so anti-kid come off as way more entitled than any of the parents posting. Especially #27, Melissa--
When my grandmother was dying, do you really feel that I should have denied her a last deathbed visit with my daughter? Do you really think that I and my two-year-old should not have been able to be part of this extremely emotionally important family event because my child *might* cry and temporarily annoy some short-tempered people on a 5-hour cross-country flight? Sorry, I disagree. I took her. And the flight went well. In fact, something interesting happened--one row in front of me and on the other side of the plane, an adult male got sick. Violently ill, vomiting loudly. No airsick bag, so he used his neighbor's used to-go food container. And he got vomit on himself, and his seat, and his neighbor, a stranger, who was trying to help him. This incident involved quite a bit of very unpleasant noise and smell which disturbed people in multiple rows on either side of him. (They had to move the guy and could not clean the seat, so the smell persisted for the rest of the flight.) I, being the prepared parent of a toddler, passed forward a pack of baby wipes when I saw them trying to clean up with tissues. The thing is, when this happened, everyone responded with sympathy towards this individual. I heard many murmurs of "poor guy..." etc--and not one single complaint, cold stare, or expression of irritation about the disruption. People were responding with normal human sympathy to another person who was uncomfortable, through no fault of his own, due to airline travel--even though his discomfort absolutely caused all of us discomfort and inconvenience as well. Why can't people respond this way when the individual in question is a kid?

The only possible justification I can see for the co-worker's attitude is that the bag was partially unzipped. (Even still, the coworker is overreacting.)

If T. starts keeping the bag zipped, that ought to be sufficient. (And other commenters have provided good advice on the issue of being discreet as far as rinsing, storing milk, etc.)

In terms of your worries in the US that ruperts little trick of closing down NOTW will work it won't, the fact is that there is a lot of upset that about 250 journalists have now lost their jobs. But the coverage is now wall to wall, and we should expect at least one arrest today, and several in the next few days.

I can't wait for the Sunday papers. Now that the staff of NOTW has been sacrificed in the hopes of salvaging News Corp's image and bottom line, what's to prevent them from selling their tell-all stories about other Internal misdeeds, in true the true tradition of the British tabloids, to the highest bidder? It'll be a bloodbath.

Politicians are all afraid of newspapers so he got away with this. Murodch saw a way to print stupidity and lies and get away with it. The damage his lies cause is real. What a pathetic man and what a pathetic lot his editors are. Its shocking how sad his company—what a sad man.

"The prime minister (Cameron) has always vouched for Mr. Coulson’s integrity and said he believed Mr. Coulson’s assurances that he had done nothing wrong."

No matter what Cameron says in public, we all know that in his heart of hearts, Cameron truly believes that Murdoch employees have done nothing wrong. The ONLY thing Cameron is worried about is his conservative revolution that seeks to take Great Britain back to the Middle Ages.

While some many people are expressing outrage about the Casey Anthony verdict, including Murdoch's FOX pundits, it might be a time to reflect on the fact that Murdoch's News of the World employees would have thought it completely acceptable to hack into the phones of the members of the Anthony family and erase messages about Cayley...even if such actions would have impeded the investigation.
